https://prez.dev/description.@value: Methods used to spatially locate geological features and exploration, mining and related infrastructure sites. These can be either features directly observed in the field (e.g. site/outcrop descriptions, structural readings, etc.) or obtained from legacy and current documents/datasets (e.g. airphotos, maps, previously published reports, exploration reports, etc.). Each location method has a spatial accuracy that indicates an estimate of the approximate error in the location. Captured geographical locations for geological or mining features are expressed as a set of coordinates (latitude and longitude degrees), with or without an elevation above or below sea level.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Geographical location obtained by using a Global Positioning System (GPS), i.e. via triangulation using at least four satellites and a receiver (such as a smartphone or GPS device). Note that the use of drones to capture GPS coordinates falls in this category.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Used by GSWA to capture locations of geological observations or exploration/mining/infrastructure sites. The Global Positioning System (GPS) is a satellite-based radio navigation system that provides geolocation and time information to a GPS receiver anywhere on or near the Earth where there is an unobstructed line of sight to four or more GPS satellites (each satellite sends information about its position and the current time, and the receiver calculates how far away each satellite is based on how long it took for the messages to arrive; then, the receiver uses this information to triangulate the user's exact position on Earth). It was fully operational by 1993.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: Geographical location obtained by using a Global Positioning System (GPS), i.e. via triangulation using at least four satellites and a receiver (such as a smartphone or GPS device). Note that the use of drones to capture GPS coordinates falls in this category.

Geographical location derived by a measurement of location and time via Global Positioning System (GPS) â€” it uses multilateration to connect a receiver to a network of satellites to determine the position coordinates of the receiver. The default coordinate system for GPS is the World Geodetic System 1984; in Australia the Geocentric Datum of Australia 1994 (or 2020) is also used. Modern GPS receivers can be accurate to 10 m.
